Arab Death Toll Rises In Clashes With Israelis Violent clashes between Palestinians and Israeli forces in the West Bank and Gaza left at least 12 dead and hundreds wounded in the third straight day of pitched street fighting set off by the defiant visit Thursday of a right-wing Israeli leader, Ariel Sharon, to the ancient mosques atop Jerusalem's Old City.

Push for Milosevic Concession Opposition leaders in Serbia anxiously await key rallies planned for tomorrow aimed at forcing President Slobodan Milosevic to concede defeat in elections last Sunday.

President Vladimir Putin of Russia offered to send his foreign minister to Belgrade to help resolve the standoff. President Clinton spoke with Mr. Putin by phone, saying the will of the Serbian people must be respected.

Fujimori's Waning Power United States officials have encouraged President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru to forge ahead with new elections, even as political experts say his influence appears to be declining. Mr. Fujimori's own prime minister has tacitly conceded that the military is restive.

Europe Delays Trade Sanctions The European Union delayed billions of dollars in sanctions against the United States stemming from a dispute over tax laws, providing a reprieve while both sides try to reduce trade tensions.
India Floods Kill More Than 900 A government team described the effects of two weeks of flooding in West Bengal state as ''pretty serious,'' with a death toll of more than 900.
NATIONAL

Candidates See Stakes Of the Debates as Critical Officials in both camps say the stakes of the presidential debate on Tuesday will be far greater than anticipated. As a result, they have suspended many strategic decisions, at least until Wednesday, so they can gauge whether the dynamics of the contest have been shifted.

The proposals for offering drug coverage to the elderly are hard to compare, but analysts say Vice President Al Gore's plan includes more financing and a higher subsidy for premiums. Advisers to Gov. George W. Bush counter that his plan offers more flexibility and more choices.
The hardest-working family in this campaign may be Dick Cheney's. His wife delivers warm-up speeches, and his two daughters are close aides.
Officials in the Bush campaign said they did not believe that an employee of the campaign's advertising firm was involved in sending debate materials to the Gore campaign.

Studios Prepare for Strikes Hollywood is bracing itself for threatened strikes by writers and actors, which could well affect what viewers around the world will see in movies and on television next year.
Churches Fight Lottery Church groups strongly oppose a state lottery plan in South Carolina, but the measure may not be defeated as video poker was last year.
Schools Try Reward System Schools in North Carolina are offering bonuses to teachers and discount cards to students, all in an effort to raise test scores.
NEW YORK/REGION

Low-Wage Jobs Are Found To Grow at a Faster Rate While the city has added thousands of high-paying Wall Street and Silicon Alley jobs in recent years, the fastest growth has been among low-wage service jobs -- those paying less than $25,000 a year -- like restaurant workers, security guards and day care workers a study by a team of economists found.

Lazio Leads In Fund-Raising Rick A. Lazio has surpassed Hillary Rodham Clinton in fund-raising, raising about four times as much money as Mrs. Clinton in the past month, and he has nearly three times as much money on hand, according to unofficial figures released by the campaigns today.

City Courts Online Deliveries City and state officials seem to be tripping over each other in the race to lure more desktop-to-doorstep delivery companies to New York with everything from grants to tax breaks.
